item.title: Portal 2: Chapter 5 Walkthrough
item.description:
Portal 2 is nothing short of a masterpiece. The game looks great, has snappy controls, brilliantly designed puzzles, and its dialog is some of the best in video game history. The game also doesn’t pull any punches when it comes to its difficulty. Transitioning from one puzzle to the next prevents players from moving back and forth wondering where to go next. The puzzles are not overly complex, and everything the players do is at their disposal for each room.

There are some exceptions to this, such as Chapter 5. Players might not notice where to go or what to do. This guide will show players what they will need to keep an eye out for and how to progress through the chapter to its end. While there is a co-op mode for Portal 2 , it does not follow the same puzzles featured in the single-player campaign.

Reaching the Spiral Tube Room of Chapter 5 in Portal 2

The first obstacle players will be faced with is a door that sticks before fully opening. Players will encounter this door at the very start of the chapter. Shoot a portal through its opening to the other side, and another portal on any of the white surfaces in the room you start in. While its use of portals may be what makes Portal 2 such an amazing puzzle game, but they see little use for this chapter. Leave this room through the door opening and onto a metal walkway. Wheatley will chime in once you do.

Following the rail that Wheatley moves along. The area will go dark, but Wheatley will turn on a light and continue moving along his rail. Keep following Wheatley until you come to a stationary conveyor belt. Hop onto this conveyor belt and follow it to the far end. There will be a platform on the left side of this conveyor belt. Keep following the metal walkway while Wheatley speaks, and you will come to a drop with a moving conveyor belt at the bottom.

Follow along this conveyor belt. There will be panels that move across it from time to time, but they are of no danger. Unlike the lasers at the other end. Watch along the left-hand side for an opening as you travel along this conveyor belt. Wheatley will sound off once you are near it. This area is easy to miss, almost as if it were a hidden area.

Quick, this way!

Move along this path while sticking to the left-hand side. You will eventually come to a broken portion of the walkway that you can jump across. After making this jump, take the first left and go up some stairs. Stop at the top of these stairs and shoot a portal on the wall in front of you. Look up and to the left to see an opening behind some railings. Shoot a portal up here and then go through the first portal you made to reach it.

Move to the railing at the other end of the room and wait for Wheatley to come along. He will shine his light on the wall for you. Shoot a portal on this wall, and then another portal anywhere in the room you are in. This will put you on a metal railing. Wheatley will then tell you where another wall is and shine his light. Shoot a portal where he shines his light, and portal travel to this spot. Follow along the walkway and take the first right. This leads to a room with a spiral tube. Walk along this spiral and then jump over the railing to the room just above the ground floor. This will lead you to a door that will open all the way.

Players can also just jump down to the bottom and make a portal on the white surface. Players can then look up to see the room with the railing and can make a portal to it.

Navigate the Assembly Lines of Chapter 5 in Portal 2

Players will end up in a monitor room. Portal to the moving conveyor belt and follow the pathway to the other moving conveyor belt. Walk to the far end and drop to the metal walkway below. Follow this path until you find a room with a turret shooting. Place a portal above this turret’s target and then another portal on the wall next to you. Shoot a turret behind the turrets that shoot at the target.

When it is safe, shoot another portal on the wall behind the target and move through it. Follow the metal walkway and go up some steps attached to it.

It is here you can grab a defective turret that is being catapulted into an incinerator. Grab it now to save time.

Keep following this path for Wheatley to show up again. Listen to his dialogue and look away for him to make an opening into the room. Use this opening to place a portal into the room and remove the master turret. Players will now be tasked with finding a new turret to use as the template.

Backtrack an use one of the defective turrets that are being catapulted. Exit the room once the door unlocks and progress through the hallways with Whetley. He will mention “Bring your daughter to work day” as you follow his rail. This will lead you to the next exit door with a loading screen. Back and forth thinking like this can make Portal 2 a great choice of game for escape room enthusiasts.

Finding GLaDOS in Chapter 5 for Portal 2

Follow the path to an elevator that will take you up. You will see a laser hitting a wall. Place a portal here. Head all the way up the stairs to a room where you can see a large white pipe with many smaller pipes leading into it. There will be a white panel moving up and down on the left, and another white panel moving along the roof on the right. Use a portal to cause the laser from earlier to cut through all the smaller pipes. This will drop the neurotoxin levels to 0%. Using turrets and lasers is the primary method of dealing damage for a lot of puzzles in the game.

The white pipe will then buckle and implode before collapsing. Leave the level you are on and make a left turn into the room with the doors that break open. Head into this room, and you will be sucked into a pipe. Once you regain control, place a portal on one of the walls. Then move to the end of the walkway and look right. You will see a light blinking on a white surface. Place a portal on this surface and move through the first portal you placed. You will end up in a room with a door that claims to lead to an emergency shut-off for GLaDOS.

GLaDOS Emergency Shutdown and Cake Dispensary. Keep unlocked.

In typical Portal fashion, this was but a lie. GLaDOS will begin monologging as the walls start to close in on the player. Drop down once an opening appears, and you will be brought towards GLaDOS. A chain of events will now occur showing the fruits of the players' sabotage throughout Chapter 5. Progress through this until there is mention of a core transfer.

Note: Many players do not realize just how massive GLaDOS actually is. Players who have seen this in VR are astounded by how intimidating she is up close in VR.

Carry Whetley and place him in the receptacle. Look between Whetley and GLaDOS with Whetley on the left. A door will open after mentioning a stalemate resolution button. GLaDOS will use panels to push the player away if they try to get close. Place a portal to the side of the button under the light, then another portal on the white floor panels.

There will now be panels that keep you from getting to the button. Put a portal on either side of the button, then run from one portal to the other and keep running until you get to the button and can press it. Place Wheatley onto GLaDOS’s body and enter the elevator when prompted. Now sit back and enjoy the rest of the chapter player out from inside the elevator and learn some new lore elements about the Portal universe.

item.title: Clash Royale: All Tower Troops, Ranked
item.description:
Since their introduction, Tower Troops have added an extra layer of strategy to Clash Royale , significantly affecting how your deck plays out. Currently, the game features four distinct Tower Troops: Dagger Duchess, Cannoneer, Royal Chef, and Tower Princess, each with its own unique strengths and weaknesses.

From rapid dagger attacks and powerful cannon blasts to stat-enhancing pancake buffs, these Tower Troops force players to rethink their strategies when they build a deck. But which one is truly the best choice to get you to the top? In this guide, we've ranked all the Tower Troops to help you choose the best one for your Clash Royale games.

4 Dagger Duchess

Fastest Attack of All Tower Troops

Rarity

Legendary

Hit Points

2768

Damage Per Second

248

Dagger Recharge Time

0.9 seconds

The Dagger Duchess used to be an excellent Tower Troop before all the nerfs it received a few seasons back. Even though it got buffed recently, it never really went back to its prime. The Tower Troop is still decent in a few cycle decks, but the other ones are simply better in the current meta.

Instead of firing a single attack, the Dagger Duchess fires multiple dagger projectiles in quick succession at the enemy unit as it crosses over to your side of the arena. However, after 8 attacks, the bar under the Crown Tower depletes and the attack speed of the tower goes down.

The bar gradually fills up again when the Dagger Duchess isn't actively attacking a troop. This means against beatdown decks that have multiple support troops behind the win condition, the Dagger Duchess pretty much becomes useless once it takes out a single troop. This Tower Troop has the second-highest hit points in the game but struggles against most decks in the meta.

3 Cannoneer

Slow Shots, Big Damage

Rarity

Epic

Hit Points

2616

Damage Per Second

160

Hit Speed

2.4 seconds

Cannoneer was the first truly new Tower Troop to be added to the game. When it first came out, the troop was pretty much broken because of its massive damage. Despite the nerfs that came afterward, a few Golem decks still go with the Cannoneer as its primary Tower Troop.

Cannoneer's biggest strength is its massive damage per hit. While its hit speed is the slowest of the bunch, the damage it deals to any enemy unit that crosses the bridge makes it a solid Tower Troop to use in your decks. It can prevent a Bomber or Firecracker from getting hit on the tower because of its high damage.

The Cannoneer's biggest weakness, however, is against decks that use swarm-type win conditions. It struggles against cards like Graveyard, and Goblin Drill and is countered heavily by most Log Bait decks. It also has the lowest hit points of all the tower troops, making it a high-risk, high-reward option for most players.

2 Royal Chef

A Unique and Powerful Ability

Rarity

Legendary

Hit Points

2703

Damage Per Second

109

Buff Cooking Time

24-40 seconds

Royal Chef is the newest Tower Troop to make its way to the Clash Royale arena. This Tower Troop doesn't have the exceptional nuke potential of the other ones that we've mentioned so far. In fact, it deals the least DPS of all the Tower Troops on this list. But what makes this Tower Troop so good is its unique Pancake Buff.

Every few seconds, the Royal Chef chucks out a Pancake towards an allied troop on the field, increasing its level by one. Simply put, if you've got a level 15 card on the field, the Pancake buff from the Royal Chef will push the troop to level 16, exponentially increasing all of its stats.

The Royal Chef can take anywhere from 24 to 60 seconds to prepare this buff. The duration is shorter when the Tower Troop is not actively attacking the enemy troops. It's also possible to buff up an allied troop multiple times with the Royal Chef. But since the buff prioritizes the unit that hasn't levelled up yet, it's more likely that it will be spread out across the different units you have on the field.

1 Tower Princess

The Most Reliable Tower Troop

Rarity

Common

Hit Points

3052

Damage Per Second

136

Hit Speed

0.8 seconds

The Tower Princess is the standard Tower Troop that players start off with in Clash Royale . Despite being a Common Tower Troop, Tower Princess is the most reliable of the bunch. It offers a nice balance of damage and attack speed despite not having any unique effects like the other Tower Troops.

The Tower Princess also has the highest hit points of all the Tower Troops. While it may not offer any additional utility, it can tank more damage before going down. Since every bit of damage counts in the top ladder, most players go with the Tower Princess as their Tower Troop unless they are running a very specific meta deck.

Even if you don't have any other tower troops unlocked, the Tower Princess will easily carry you to the Ultimate Champion. It may not offer the burst damage of Dagger Duchess or the nuke of the Cannoneer, but it offers consistency, making it our top pick for the best tower troop in Clash Royale .

item.title: Marvel Rivals: Best Rush Characters
item.description:
Summary

  • Scarlet Witch excels in rushing enemies, stunning with Dark Seal, and devastating with her ultimate.
  • Storm deals high damage, boosts allies, and has a powerful ultimate that wrecks foes in a group.
  • The Thing is an immovable Vanguard with a ram ability that launches enemies and provides damage reduction.

Fans can choose from the various Duelists, Strategists, and Vanguards in Marvel Rivals , but it is also important to take into account the unnamed archetypes of characters that players can choose from in the hero-shooter game. These are: Poke, dive, and rush characters.

Rush characters usually have a decent amount of health, deal moderate damage, and like to attack from mid-close range. Rush characters excel at pushing an objective and attacking from the front line. While dive and poke heroes fulfill their roles, rush characters like to engage Vanguards and other Duelists that are playing up on the front line.

8 Scarlet Witch

Auto-Lock Damage And Mobility

Scarlet Witch is often regarded as one of the easiest Duelist heroes to play due to her auto-lock primary fire. While her auto-lock primary fire drains an opponent's health with ease, utilizing her correctly is still very important. Scarlet excels in rushing in on enemies and draining their health while they're currently in a fight with Wanda's allies.

Scarlet Witch can also use her Dark Seal ability to continuously stun an enemy caught in the ability's AoE. Her ultimate, which has been buffed in Season 1, will immediately take out all foes caught in the ultimate ability's wide vicinity, which is devastating when used strategically.

7 Storm

Devastating Damage And Rapid Movement Boosts

After Season 1 had been released, Storm became one of the most-played DPS heroes in the game. She deals great damage, boosts her allies' speed and damage, and her ultimate ability can destroy foes who are caught in a compact group.

Storm is a flying Duelist who can boost her teammates' damage and speed with Weather Control and Goddess Boost. Storm also has a team-up ability with Human Torch that creates a large fiery tornado with her ultimate move, dealing enough damage to eliminate Luna Snow out of her ultimate ability.

6 The Thing

An Immovable Force

The Thing is a fantastic Vanguard in Marvel Rivals with one of the most prominent passive abilities: He is unable to be moved by any enemy moves, such as Spider-Man's "Get Over Here!" ability. While he can't be moved, The Thing can be stunned by abilities like Doctor Strange's ultimate. The Thing prominently rushes through the enemy's front line with his ram ability that prohibits the use of mobility moves and launches enemies up into the air.

Thing can also jump back into battle using his Embattled Leap ability to move across the map toward an ally and provide them with damage reduction. His ultimate ability will stun a group of enemies and launch them into the air, which is great for easy eliminations when synergized with teammates.

5 Wolverine

Vanguards' Worst Nightmare

Wolverine, one of the most banned heroes in competitive play, is known to be a grand threat to most Vanguards in Marvel Rivals . That's because he deals damage to enemies based on their health pool. Using his Feral Leap ability, Wolverine can 'kidnap' a target, fly them back toward his allies, and slash through the enemy with his teammates for an easy pick.

This works exceptionally well on Vanguard enemies since Wolverine deals more damage to them with his vicious claws. When Wovlerine's health is depleted, his passive ability grants him bonus health that acts as a healing factor for the X-Men hero, allowing him to stay alive even longer through important fights.

4 Human Torch

A Fiery DPS With Amazing Damage Potential

The Human Torch is another flying character in Marvel Rivals that essentially deals more damage the closer he is played to enemies. His primary fire acts as a fiery shotgun blast that, when point-blank, deals massive damage that can eliminate a target in two shots. Human Torch can also use Blazing Blasts to not only create fiery AoE attacks but also connect them to form flaming walls.

With four connected into a box, any enemy within the walls continuously takes damage, creating an oven of damage that allies can take quick advantage of. When needed, Human Torch can use Flaming Meteor to either dive away from enemies or dive onto low-health targets to achieve fast eliminations.

3 The Incredible Hulk

A Monstrous Tank With Versatility

Like Wolverine, Hulk is one of the most banned heroes in competitive games. Hulk is a very versatile tank hero in Marvel Rivals that can focus damage wherever needed, though he mostly focuses on 'squishy' targets. Using his leaping ability, Hulk is also very mobile, and can even attack while leaping around. On an airborne character, Hulk can also tackle them out of the sky and slam them into the ground.

His ultimate ability unleashes a stronger and larger form of Hulk (Monster Hulk) that thrashes around, sending enemies flying everywhere. Monster Hulk's 'ultimate' allows him to grab a target and slam them around, finishing them off with a stomp.

2 Mister Fantastic

A Hybrid DPS With Tank Potential

Mister Fantastic is one of Marvel Rival's best hybrid characters, as he attacks from afar and can engage targets up close. Mister Fantastic has a large health pool as a Duelist character (350hp) and gains 450 bonus health when he activates his inflated state.

While in his normal form, his punches deal damage from a medium range, and he can absorb lots of damage using his Reflexive Rubber ability. These moves help Mister Fantastic to activate his Elastic Strength passive faster, which inflates Mister Fantastic, giving him bonus health and giving his attacks even more damage.

1 Winter Soldier

Ranged Gunfighter With An Exceptional Kit

Winter Soldier is regarded as one of the best Duelists in the game due to his passive ability, damage capability, and overall kit. With his pistol, Winter Soldier deals a moderate amount of damage, yet can quickly KO an enemy when targeted correctly.

His abilities will automatically reload his pistol and give Winter Soldier bonus health, encouraging players to combo his primary shots with his different abilities. Winter Soldier can use Bionic Hook to pull in a target, shoot them with his pistol, and then use Trooper's Fist to finish them off. If needed, Winter Soldier would have his pistol reloaded to deal extra damage, and another ability left to combo with.

item.title: Fallout 76: 9 Overpowered Builds That Are A Lot Of Fun
item.description:
Summary

  • Fallout 76 had a rocky start but has improved.
  • Players need to choose the right stats and build.
  • Different builds can make the game experience fun and overpowered.

Fallout 76 had something of a rocky launch back in 2018. Who can forget the Bobby Pin fiasco in the first few weeks of the game being live? Fortunately, Bethesda quickly patched most of the game-breaking problems quite quickly, resulting in a competitive live-service game that maintains a healthy player base to this day.

As a competitive PvP game, with plenty of PvE content set on an open-world map, choosing the right stats, build and equipment is a crucial aspect of gameplay. Players of other Fallout games will instantly feel at home with the Fallout 76 take on leveling and builds, as it shares many common aspects with, for example, Fallout 4 . However, there are some builds that are simply unbalanced, and when done right, are completely overpowered.

Updated on February 25, 2025, by Gerardo Molina: There's a lot of debate on whether Fallout 4 is better than Fallout 76. However, it's really important to consider that they’re two completely different beasts. While Fallout 4 might offer a richer narrative experience, Fallout 76 definitely has more options in terms of perks and things to do. Many of the builds mentioned in this list do not use all the available points allotted to each attribute, but this is simply to give players more freedom regarding any other Perk they might want to add. What’s included is merely a suggestion and experimenting further is recommended to get the ultimate build for the wasteland.

9 Firestarter

Decimate Enemies And Go Out In A Blaze Of Glory

Strength Perception Endurance Charisma Intelligence Agility Luck
Bear Arms Grenadier Fireproof Bodyguards Demolition Expert Last Laugh
Blocker Exterminator Bullet Shield Friendly Fire
Expert Heavy Gunner Chem Fiend
  • Strength: 18
  • Perception: 2
  • Endurance: 12
  • Charisma: 6
  • Intelligence: 3
  • Agility: 13
  • Luck: 13

The Firestarter build is great for players who want to bring down their enemies in a blaze of glory without having to worry about taking excessive damage. Using the Heavy Incinerator and the Bolstering Legendary Armor mod, as well as the Fireproof Perk and the Speed Demon and Healing Factor mutations, players can ensure that they’ll remain mostly unaffected by anything enemies throw at them.

This might not be the quickest build out there, but that doesn't really matter when enemies succumb to players’ might in the blink of an eye.

8 Tesla Arc Blaster

The Ultimate Electrical Menace

Strength Perception Endurance Charisma Intelligence Agility Luck
Full Charge Refractor Adamantium Skeleton Bodyguards Batteries Included Action Boy/Action Girl Better Criticals
Demolition Expert Revenant Supressor Gunsmith Born Survivor Class Freak
Concentrated Fire Lead Belly Tenderizer Science Gun Fu Grim Reapers Sprint
Exterminator
Glow Sight
  • Strength: 5
  • Perception: 19
  • Endurance: 4
  • Charisma: 7
  • Intelligence: 7
  • Agility: 19
  • Luck: 15

The Tesla rifle is not appreciated enough in Fallout 76, which is a shame, since it can be really powerful when paired with the right Perks and other elements. The Tesla Arc Blaster build relies heavily on the Tesla Bracers and Unyielding Armor mods, as well as the Energy Resistance and Demolition Expert Perks.

Combined with the Electrically Charged and Speed Demon mutations, players will quickly find that it’s extremely simple to bring enemies down with the power of lighting, no matter how tough they are.

7 Drunken Blademaster

Mr. Handy Buzzblades And Alcohol

Strength Perception Endurance Charisma Intelligence Agility Luck
Blocker Grenadier Adamantium Skeleton Happy Go Lucky First Aid Action Boy Bloody Mess
Expert Slugger Chem Fiend Inspirational Makeshift Warrior Born Survivor Class Freak
Incisor Chem Resistant Party Boy Gun Fu Four Leaf Clover
Master Slugger Fireproof Squad Manouveur Marathoner Grim Reapers Sprint
Slugger Professional Drinker Strange In Numbers Thru Hiker Mysterious Saviour
Starched Genes
  • Strength: 18
  • Perception: 2
  • Endurance: 12
  • Charisma: 6
  • Intelligence: 3
  • Agility: 13
  • Luck: 13

This build for Fallout 76, uses two specific features to create both a capable and fun build to play. It is, of course, a melee build. Firstly, it relies on using different versions of Mr. Handy Blades to use on specific targets. Secondly, it opens up the option to use alcohol for combat buffs, which is pretty good fun and surprisingly effective.

Fallout 76 players can also change this build a little bit and use axes or chainsaws instead, although these have been nerfed somewhat in recent times, with the chainsaw no longer being able to wind up while moving, and the stagger on axes being reduced. Using the Mr. Handy Blades is arguably the best choice, but it could be worth experimenting with.

6 Bloody Rifleman

Specializing In Using The Railway Rifle

Strength Perception Endurance Charisma Intelligence Agility Luck
Bandolier Commando Lead Belly Inspirational Batteries Included Action Boy Bloody Mess
Traveling Pharmacy Concentrated Fire Life Giver Strange In Numbers Demolition Expert Born Survivor Class Freak
Expert Commando Radicool Tenderizer Gunsmith Adrenaline Better Criticals
Ground Pounder Nerd Rage Gun Fu Critical Savvy
Master Commando Scrapper Thru Hiker Serendipity
Tank Killer Starched Genes
  • Strength: 5
  • Perception: 15
  • Endurance: 2
  • Charisma: 2
  • Intelligence: 15
  • Agility: 7
  • Luck: 10

This build for Fallout 76 is both incredibly simple to set up and amazingly effective in combat. It is exceptionally well suited to players who are tired of playing a basic commando build. It revolves around a single weapon; the quad railway rifle. For newer players who can’t get hold of a 4-start railway rifle yet, the build will still work with a 1-star version, just not as well.

Power armor is optional with this build, but it will be useful whilst leveling up, or for players who don’t yet have the 4-star variant of the railway rifle to finish the build off. Something else to consider with this build is that it is also very good for farming experience, due to the high intelligent stat.

5 EXP Farmer

Piling On The Experience Points

Strength Perception Endurance Charisma Intelligence Agility Luck
Bandolier Green Thumb Chem Fiend Happy Go Lucky First Aid Thru Hiker Curator
Arms Keeper Night Person Chem Resistant Inspirational Chemist Good With Salt
Bear Arms Pannapictagraphist Cola Nut Party Boy Contractor Class Freak
Ordnance Express Percepti-Bobble Good Doggy Strange in Numbers Nerd Rage Starched Genes
Pack Rat Hydro Fix Pharmacist Super Duper
Sturdy Frame Munchy Resistant Power Patcher
Traveling Pharmacy Rejuvenated Scrapper
  • Strength: 8
  • Perception: 1
  • Endurance: 14
  • Charisma: 8
  • Intelligence: 15
  • Agility: 3
  • Luck: 7

This build for Fallout 76 is overpowered in a different way. Whilst it is quite flat from a combat perspective, it will maximize the amount of exp that players earn whilst playing. This gives something of a blank slate for the player to build on.

Equipment choices are going to be down to the individual and what their preferred playing style is. Most players who use this build in Fallout 76 will rely on crafting to farm exp, rather than combat anyway. Overall, this build will see the player level up as fast as possible in the game.

4 VATS Rifleman

Serious Ranged Damage

Strength Perception Endurance Charisma Intelligence Agility Luck
Bandolier Expert Rifleman Fireproof Tenderizer Nerd Rage Adrenaline Better Criticals
Sturdy Frame Concentrated Fire Radicool Lone Wanderer Demolition Expert Covert Operative Bloody Mess
Traveling Pharmacy Master Rifleman Escape Artist Class Freak
Rifleman Gun Fu Critical Savvy
Tank Killer Sneak Grim Reaper's Sprint
Mister Sandman Starched Genes
  • Strength: 2
  • Perception: 15
  • Endurance: 4
  • Charisma: 7
  • Intelligence: 3
  • Agility: 15
  • Luck: 10

This Fallout 76 offers completely overpowered ranged damage and critical hits. The whole idea of this build is to boost the effectiveness of VATS to score as many accurate critical hits as possible. This is very much a glass cannon build and is not intended for any form of close-quarters combat.

The equipment best used with this build is going to be light armor, something like the Secret Service Armor for example. Weapon choice is down to the player. Any long-range rifle is suitable, and this makes the weapon upgrade path quite simple as the player progresses with this build.

3 Basic Commando

Simple To Play But Still Fun

Strength Perception Endurance Charisma Intelligence Agility Luck
Bandolier Commando Fireproof Field Surgeon First Aid Action Boy Better Criticals
Sturdy Frame Concentrated Fire Strange in Numbers Gunsmith Adrenaline Bloody Mess
Traveling Pharmacy Expert Commando Tenderizer Scrapper Escape Artist Class Freak
Ground Pounder Marathoner Starched Genes
Master Commando White Knight
Tank Killer
  • Strength: 6
  • Perception: 15
  • Endurance: 1
  • Charisma: 6
  • Intelligence: 7
  • Agility: 10
  • Luck: 11

As Fallout 76 builds go, this is a pretty straightforward one. It focuses on dealing heavy damage. Survivability is a secondary focus, as this is something of a glass cannon build. That being said, this is by no means a paper-thin build.

Weapon-wise, the player will need to use something like the Railway Rifle as soon as they can, which means unlocking the recipe at level 30. The Automatic Piston Receiver weapon mod is vital for this weapon as well. Heavy Combat Armor will provide basic protection and some decent stat boosts.

2 One Shot, One Kill

Totally Overpowered Plasma Gunner

Strength Perception Endurance Charisma Intelligence Agility Luck
Heavy Gunner Glow Sight Radicool Inspirational Batteries Included Action Boy Better Criticals
Expert Heavy Gunner Concentrated Fire Suppressor Nerd Rage Adrenaline Bloody Mess
Master Heavy Gunner Tenderizer Power User Gun Fu Critical Savvy
Lock and Load Stabilized Four Leaf Clover
Ricochet
  • Strength: 7
  • Perception: 6
  • Endurance: 1
  • Charisma: 9
  • Intelligence: 7
  • Agility: 11
  • Luck: 15

The idea behind this ridiculously overpowered Fallout 76 build, is to stack as much critical damage as possible when using VATS in combination with a plasma caster. As the name of this build suggests, it is all about dropping a single enemy in one shot.

This build is somewhat dependent on equipment though. First of all, the player will need to find themselves a good Bloody Plasma Caster. Secondly, it needs a specific power armor set, the T-65 Power Armor to be completely effective. Therefore, this is definitely a late-game build, as new players will not have access to the equipment needed to turn it into an overpowered close-quarters, ranged damage monster.

1 Melee Monster

High Melee Damage And Power Armor

Strength Perception Endurance Charisma Intelligence Agility Luck
Expert Slugger Expert Picklock Aquaboy Inspirational Nerd Rage Action Boy Bloody Mess
Incisor Master Picklock Radicool Overly Generous Power Patcher Adrenaline Good With Salt
Martial Artist Picklock Lifegiver Strange in Numbers Power User Escape Artist Class Freak
Master Slugger Rejuvenated Tenderizer Starched Genes
Slugger Solar Powered Travel Agent
  • Strength: 10
  • Perception: 3
  • Endurance: 6
  • Charisma: 10
  • Intelligence: 9
  • Agility: 9
  • Luck: 9

Melee builds can be incredibly overpowered in Fallout 76 . The downside of a good melee build though, is that they generally don’t start to shine until the late game. This build follows this ethos. It is completely instant once the player has sourced the right equipment to use with it.

The cornerstone of this build is having access to a good power suit, and players may struggle to stay alive before they have suitable armor. Melee weapon choice is fluid, with the player switching weapons to suit the target.

item.title: Honkai: Star Rail – Tribbie Team Composition Guide
item.description:
Tribbie

Quantum

Harmony

5-Star

Guides

Build Guide

Level-Up Materials

Team Composition

Best Light Cone

Back to All Characters

The Path of Harmony in Honkai: Star Rail is applied to characters who focus on buffing their teammates. These units can take some DPS to a whole new level if players successfully match the Harmony unit's skills and the DPS' kit, like pairing Sunday with summoners, or Robin with follow-up attackers.

Then there's Tribbie—a Harmony character in Honkai: Star Rail who works with everyone in terms of buff but is also packed with powerful sub-DPS hits. So, instead of determining which DPS works with her buffing, creating Tribbie team comp in HSR will revolve around how to maximize her damage using the team's workflow.

Tribbie Team Overview In HSR - Honkai: Star Rail

Unlike units such as Robin and Tingyun who are limited to ATK-focused DPS, Tribbie brings All-Type RES PEN to the team and DMG-taken debuff for the enemies ​​​​​​. This means Tribbie is a generalist Harmony character who works with practically any DPS in the game , even HP-DPS like Blade and Mydei.

Tribbie's value rises if players lack Harmony units, but drops if they have plenty. This is because most characters in Tribbie team comp in HSR basically already have other Harmony designed for them. For example, Tribbie works perfectly with Feixiao + Topaz + Aventurine , but so does Robin.

Another key point to consider when building Tribbie team comp in HSR is her sub-DPS abilities , which can be summarized as such:

  • Tribbie's Basic Attack is a Blast-hit without any condition.
  • When an ally uses Ultimate, Tribbie launches a follow-up attack (FUA), up to 1 time per character. The counter resets when Tribbie uses her Ultimate.
  • After other ally targets attack, Tribbie regenerates 1.5 Energy for each target hit .
  • Tribbie's Ultimate deals DMG to all enemies, and creates a zone that increases the enemy's DMG taken. When an ally attacks a target, for every 1 target hit, deal 1 instance of Quantum DMG to the enemy with the highest HP among the hit targets .
  • While the zone lasts, Tribbie's Max HP increases by an amount equal to 9% of the sum of all ally characters' Max HP.
  • All of Tribbie's hits scale with HP.

So, even though Tribbie works with everyone, the following teammate criteria will make Tribbie a powerful sub-DPS:

  • Use Ultimate often.
  • Has AoE hits instead of single-target.
  • Hits often, like having follow-up attacks.
  • Packed with HP.

Tribbie Team Comp In HSR - Honkai: Star Rail

Following the aforementioned teammate criteria, here are some examples of Tribbie team comp in HSR :

Tribbie Team Comp

Fulfilled Criteria

The Herta + Jade + Lingsha

  • Use Ultimate often.
  • Everyone has AoE hits.
  • Jade and Lingsha have FUA.

Aglaea+ Sunday + Huohuo

  • Use Ultimate often.
  • Aglaea has plenty of AoE hits.

Yunli + Sunday + Huohuo

  • Use Ultimate often.
  • Yunli has AoE hits.
  • Yunli has FUA.

Argenti + Sunday + Huohuo

  • Use Ultimate often.
  • Argenti has AoE hits.

Jing Yuan + Sunday + Huohuo

  • Use Ultimate often.
  • Jing Yuan has AoE hits.
  • Jing Yuan has FUA.

Blade + Jade + Fu Xuan

  • Use Ultimate often.
  • Everyone has AoE hits.
  • Jade and Blade have FUA.
  • Blade and Fu Xuan are packed with HP.

Acheron (E2) + Jiaoqiu + Aventurine

  • Use Ultimate often.
  • Everyone has AoE hits.
  • Aventurine has FUA.

Feixiao + Topaz + Aventurine

  • Use Ultimate often.
  • Everyone has FUA.
